ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We had a few guests who gave live virtual lectures to our seminar group.

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Ability to communicate better about viewed dance.
I learned how to analyze and describe movement
I think my critical analysis and writing skills improved a lot in this class. Clarity of ideas also improved.

This course undoubtedly improved my writing. Specifically, I learned how to write about dance, but in a broader sense, I learned how to fuse vivid description with clear and original argument. This is much harder than it sounds, and I feel that the structure of the course assignments gave me the chance to spend ample time focusing on honing this skill. We wrote five short exercises describing single dances or comparing two dances, chose one of the exercises to revise, and wrote a final essay that gave us the chance for greater development of the skills we'd started to learn from the shorter assignments. Additionally, I learned how to describe dance verballywe would watch clips for homework along with our readings and discuss our reactions to them in class. Being specific about what you respond to in a creative work, rather than just discussing it in broad strokes, takes practice, and it's a skill I believe I'll be able to apply to all of my courses.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strength: Broadening students viewership of dance styles
Weakness: If you really dislike certain styles and try to keep an open mind, it can still be hard to discuss them and find positive things to say/not insult the others in class who really like those styles.
Strengths: incorporation of dance movement, format and guests

Strengths: 
-as I mentioned above, the writing assignments we were expected to do and the way they flowed, each one gradually building on skills we'd acquired in the previous one, were fantastic. 
-after we submitted each writing assignment, Professor Seibert would choose 3 exercises for us to workshop in class (without names attached). Talking about what worked in other people's assignments and what could be improved was extremely helpful for my own writing, I found.
-the readings and videos assigned were always INCREDIBLY engaging! although the readings and videos together took a fair amount of time to complete, i always looked forward to doing my homework for this class.
-the guest lectures!! 

Weaknesses:
-I can't think of much, but I did sometimes feel that the structure of the seminars could be switched up a little to keep things interesting. The watch dance clips, discuss dance clips routine was frequently repeated, and occasionally (but not usually, because the material was so interesting!) got tedious.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Having all the videos viewable on canvas was great. Some classes make you hunt or go to several websites for videos but they were all uploaded in the same place which was good. Watching videos in class wasn't great due to lag, if everyone turns off their cameras it can help with the lag.
The discussion was sucessful. I think it can be difficult to have longer classes like this one over zoom but overall it worked well.

-in a normal year, when professional dancers and/or other dance professors visited us, we would have been in a studio and been able to try out movements with them. Although nothing, of course, can match this experience, I felt that Professor Seibert and the guests still found ways to make the most of their virtual visits! We tried out dance that was specifically modified to fit in our home spaces, and this felt extremely creative and exciting.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think I would if they enjoy dance and want to know more about it's history in America and how to talk about it.
Yes if they are interested in dance and want to improve their writing.

Absolutely!! If you are at all interested in dance, understanding how historical styles inform modern styles, thinking about how American dance reflects and/or deviates from American ideology at various points throughout history, and/or becoming a better writer, this course will fascinate you! Do keep in mind, though, that the writing component is significant--the course is as much about learning how to meaningfully describe dance as it is about dance history.
